I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on (i) a proposed loan 
and (ii) a proposed grant, both to the Republic of the Maldives for the Inclusive Micro, Small, and 
Medium-Sized Enterprise Development Project.1 
 
2.  The  project  will  promote  economic  inclusion  in  the  Maldives  by  bolstering  economic 
activities, including in remote islands, through more opportunities and access to finance for micro, 
small,  and  medium-sized  enterprises  (MSMEs)  and  thereby  contribute  to  private  sector 
development  and  overall  economic  growth.  This  will  be  achieved  through stronger  business 
development infrastructure, better access to market information, and broader access to finance.  
 
II.  THE PROJECT 
 
A.  Rationale  
 
3.  The Maldives has been confronted in recent years with several challenges that had a 
severe impact on the economy. In December 2004, the ravages of the tsunami destroyed, in 
relative terms, a higher share of natural infrastructure in the Maldives than in any of the other 
stricken economies. In 2007, the country was mired in its own fiscal crisis linked to excessive 
spending and acute structural distortions in the economy, which was further compounded by the 
slowdown in tourism after the global crisis. In 2008, the Maldives managed a difficult transition to 
democracy, which, in the interim and given the resulting uncertainty, led to capital outflow and 
limited investment in the economy.   
 
4.  While  much  effort  has  focused  on  rebuilding  the  economy,  the  government  is  now 
concentrating on the pursuit of more inclusive growth to rectify some pressing shortcomings such 
as the lack of economic opportunities outside of Malé and the skewed concentration of ―enclave‖ 
economic activity in the resorts-based tourism industry. Political, administrative, and economic 
decentralization will support this goal, and greater availability of credit is an important platform to 
promote financial inclusion and engender economic and employment opportunities. 
 
5.  The Maldives has an overall unemployment rate of 15.4%, and youth unemployment is 
even  higher  at  around 25%.  Income  disparities  between Malé  and the  atolls  are  large  and 
increasing. The Gini coefficient has remained almost constant over time at around 0.4, which is 
notably higher than that in neighboring countries. Over time inequality between Malé and the 
atolls has steadily increased. MSME development has been prioritized by the government as one 
of the key solutions toward fostering greater economic inclusion, and the lack of access to finance 
as the most significant impediment to the promotion and development of MSMEs. As part of its 
earlier  effort  to  support  inclusive  growth  through  private  sector  development,  the  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) approved a technical assistance loan in 2008 for the Private Sector 
Development Project (PSDP) to support MSMEs in the Maldives.2 
 
6.  Achievements under the Private Sector Development Project. MSME development is 
part of the development strategy for the Maldives under the 7th National Plan, 2006–2010. Until 
2011, there was no official definition of MSMEs in the Maldives. Furthermore, the local banks had 
no direction or guidelines on how to assist MSMEs. The major achievements under the PSDP 
include (i) establishment of a central business development service center (BDSC) and two field 
                                                
1 The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
2 ADB. 2008. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors: Proposed Technical Assistance 
Loan to the Republic of the Maldives for the Private Sector Development Project. Manila.

2     
BDSCs; (ii) establishment of a cost-sharing facility (CSF) (SDR0.6 million), a line-of-credit facility 
(LCF)  (SDR1.8  million),  and  a  credit  information  bureau  (CIB),  and  a  feasibility  study  on  a 
centralized  movable  asset  registry  (now  referred  to  as  secured  transaction  registry  [STR]); 
(iii) provision of business counseling and mentoring for over 500 entrepreneurs; (iv) start-up of 55 
new  MSMEs;  (v)  completion  of  business  training,  and  counseling  for  more  than 
4,000 beneficiaries, 41% of whom were women; (vi) launch of a BDSC web portal to promote 
BDSC services and dissemination of information related to MSME registration and CSF and LCF 
application procedures; and (vii) public–private partnership (PPP) capacity building that included 
developing a PPP framework and piloting three PPP initiatives. Around 60 MSMEs in fisheries, 
tourism, arts, and handicrafts have benefited from the LCF, which helped expand their business 
operations, develop their capacity for accessing finance from the banks, and formalize the MSME 
sector through registration.3 
 
7.  Remaining  challenges.  The  success  of  the  PSDP 4  led  to  further  demand  from 
stakeholders  for  continued,  demonstration-based  support.  The  PSDP  resulted  in  the  market 
demanding additional and more sophisticated business development services (BDS). Further 
work is needed to (i) improve the quality and depth of BDS on offer; (ii) add a range of new BDS; 
and  (iii)  expand  the  geographic  coverage  of  BDS  to  ensure  countrywide  availability.  Even 
conservative assessments indicate a large unmet credit demand of $15 million–$30 million from 
MSMEs. Despite the PSDP’s success in improving access to finance, considerable work remains 
to be done to bridge this gap. Given the stringent collateral requirements imposed by banks, a 
mechanism for reviewing collateral requirements will need to be developed.5 Similarly, a credible 
mechanism to record movable assets that can serve to meet strict collateral requirements will 
need to be provided. The use of information and communication technology (ICT) innovations 
reduces transaction costs for financing, which opens up new markets for MSME products and 
services, and better targets MSMEs, especially in geographically dispersed islands. Furthermore, 
the Maldives faces significant energy challenges since imported diesel meets nearly 80% of its 
energy requirements.6  
 
8.  Lessons.  As  recommended  by  the  Independent  Evaluation  Department’s  country 
assistance program evaluation,7 continued engagement with a sector and a long-term focus will 
enable better policy dialogue, improve sector outcome, and increase development impact. The 
PSDP is a pilot project that could not cover some areas (e.g., establishment of the STR due to the 
limited resource envelope and providing sufficient time for the STR project feasibility study). 
Accordingly, although the PSDP has been successful within its limited scope and resources, 
further  support  is  essential  for  continued  and  sustainable  credit  delivery.  To  bolster  project 
delivery, any further assistance should be provided in a phased manner and should address both 
the supply and demand sides of MSME development. The assistance should also focus on 
delivering the elements of the MSME Act that the government has submitted to Parliament. The 
Maldives country partnership strategy (CPS), 2007–2011 followed a sequential approach of first

high as 120% of the value of the loan. Only houses and boats can be submitted as collateral.

providing  much-needed  capacity  development  assistance  and  intervention  to  improve  the 
enabling environment for private sector development; and thereafter, resuming investment lending 
in the CPS priority sectors of energy, transport, and MSME development.8 The project is fully 
aligned with CPS and the objectives of ADB’s Financial Sector Operational Plan and has been 
closely coordinating with the development partners.9  
 
9.  Work  under  the  project  preparatory  technical  assistance  indicated  that  the  major 
constraints identified at the launch of the PSDP had been largely addressed.10 However, there is 
an unfinished agenda from the PSDP in terms of setting up the STR, creating a credit guarantee 
scheme, extending BDS across the country, and increasing credit lending under the LCF. The 
proposed project will focus on financial inclusion; hence, it is important to extend the coverage 
and the outreach of the PSDP in solving MSME issues such as limited market access, lack of 
internal capacity, and the high cost of financing, transportation, and power. Some key lessons 
from the PSDP include the need for (i) continued institutional strengthening, (ii) market-oriented 
skills development for MSMEs, (iii) sustainability of the initiatives taken under the PSDP, (iv) a 
strong and independent project management unit, and (v) an organizational change management 
process involving stakeholders. These lessons are embedded in the project design. 
   
B.   Impact and Outcome 
 
10.  The impact will be a more inclusive and broad-based MSME sector. The outcome will be a 
further expanded and strengthened MSME sector. For this purpose, the project will strengthen the 
business  environment  and  support  infrastructure  for  doing  business  with  better  knowledge, 
greater access to financing, and expanded business opportunities for MSMEs. 
 
C.   Outputs 
 
1.  Component 1: Business Support Infrastructure Built (Demand Side) 
 
11.  Component  1  will  increase  MSME  access  to  BDS  and  support  institutional  capacity 
building for BDSCs by (i) expanding BDSCs’ geographical coverage to all seven provinces; 
(ii) introducing  new  BDS,  including  business  incubator  programs;  (iii)  strengthening  the 
institutional, operational, infrastructure, and human resource capacity of the expanded BDSCs to 
better  support  demand  of  MSMEs;  and  (iv)  transitioning  the  BDSCs  under  a  corporate 
governance development plan into a viable and privately managed BDS delivery network.11  
 
12.  Output  1:  Program  implementation  capacity  strengthened  and  enabling 
environment for MSME development improved. Output 1 will include capacity building of the 
Ministry of Economic Development (MED), Maldives Monetary Authority (MMA), and Bank of 
Maldives (BML), and setting up project management units (PMUs) at these entities. Output 1 will 
also strengthen the legal framework for (i) broader access to finance; and (ii) commercial laws 
pertaining to MSMEs, including new e-commerce and data protection laws. Furthermore, women 
in the Maldives, particularly those in the outer islands, are excluded from participation in MSME

development  due  to  traditional  stereotyping  of  their  role,  and  the  reluctance  of  young 
entrepreneurs to engage in traditional activities such as fisheries and agriculture. To increase their 
participation, interventions  envisaged would  include  exercises to  build marketable skills,  and 
special provisions such as earmarking part of the LCF for this segment.  
 
13.  Output 2: Business development service centers and business incubator programs 
strengthened. The project will strengthen the capacity of the BDSC network, broaden the range 
of products and services offered, improve the capacity of BDSCs to better serve business needs 
of MSMEs, and increase BDSC operational performance and business profitability. Two BDSC-
operated business incubator facilities—one in the north and the other in the south—will work with 
selected MSMEs under business partnership agreements. MSME selection will be based on 
transparent selection criteria.12 
 
14.  Output 3: Credit guarantee scheme initiated. A consultancy will be provided for (i) 
designing  and  making  credit  guarantee  schemes  operational  toward  reducing  the  collateral 
requirement for MSMEs, (ii) initiating a credit guarantee fund to diminish the risk incurred by 
lenders  and  ease  access  to  credit  for  MSMEs  without  sufficient  collateral  to  meet  bank 
requirements; and (iii) undertaking a public awareness campaign to explain the key features of the 
fund. Following a preparatory consultancy, the fund will start with the capital contributed by the 
government, and a new entity will be established to manage the fund.  
 
2.    Component 2: Access to Finance Improved (Supply Side) 
 
15.  Component 2 will improve MSME access to finance by (i) adding to the LCF to meet the 
huge credit demand from MSMEs, (ii) extending the CIB to improve information quality and 
reduce credit risk, and (iii) establishing an STR database on fixed and movable assets.  
 
16.   Output 1: Line-of-credit facility expanded. An additional LCF of $8.5 million will be built 
with feedback from MED and BML on the implementation of the pilot LCF, which was set up under 
the PSDP to promote a culture of lending to MSMEs with less restrictive collateral requirements 
and cash-flow-based financing.13 Of this, $1.5 million will be financed by ADB and $7 million by 
the Islamic Development Bank (IDB). The government will relend the $1.5 million to BML through 
a subsidiary loan agreement, detailing the terms and conditions of onlending by BML to eligible 
MSMEs according   to   the   eligibility   criteria14   mutually   agreed   by   ADB   and   the 
government.15 The loan term will not exceed 15 years, including a 3-year grace period, with the

government retaining the right to close the LCF.16 MOFT will cause BML to ensure that qualified 
enterprises  procure  goods,  works,  and  consulting  services  in  accordance  with  procurement 
procedures  acceptable  to  ADB.17 BML  has  experience  with  development  banking  and  an 
adequate  number  of  professional  staff  to  administer  the  expanded  LCF,  as  shown  in  the 
successful  implementation  of  the  pilot  LCF.  BML  will  be  required  to  satisfy,  and  remain  in 
compliance with, the eligibility criteria throughout the project period.18  
 
17.  Output 2: Credit information bureau enhanced. Established under the MMA, the CIB is 
a central repository of credit histories (positive and negative) of borrowers. Output 2 will (i) expand 
the membership (including telecommunication and utility companies; and other nonbank credit 
providers such as insurance companies, student loan providers, and other public and private 
credit providers); (ii) develop new reporting and credit scoring products, including customized 
products to meet individual member’s information needs; and (iii) raise public awareness about 
the need for building a credit track record, explaining the role of the CIB in lending decisions, and 
assisting the development of a positive credit reputation. 
 
18.  Output 3: Secured transaction registry established. In line with a feasibility study under 
the PSDP, an STR will be established under the MMA to help MSMEs with sound business 
financials to secure credit against movable assets and thus facilitate access to finance for such 
enterprises even if they do not have adequate collateral. Output 3 will include (i) as-is and 
requirement  analysis,  and  technical  specification  based  on  internationally  acceptable  best 
practices; and (ii) establishment of an online and publicly searchable STR recording the interests 
of financiers in assets, and helping credit providers to take security over movable property, and 
find out pre-existing charges against assets and priority position of multiple charges on assets. 
 
3.  Component 3: Technologies for Micro, Small, and Medium-Sized Enterprise 
Development Established (Market Development)  
 
19.  Component 3 will enable the use of ICT to promote information and knowledge sharing 
between  MSMEs  and  with  the  government;  and  implementation  of  a  pilot  ICT  project  to 
(i) demonstrate the viability of solar energy as a cost-effective energy option; (ii) create a platform 
for delivery of e-governance services, such as e-commerce and e-payment through citizen service 
centers (CSCs); and (iii) create a revenue stream for BDSCs to increase their contribution to the 
gross domestic product. To ensure the feasibility of the proposed CSCs, an initial study on the 
proposed location and methodology will be conducted. 
 
20.  Output  1:  Micro,  small,  and  medium-sized  enterprise  portal  and  judgment  debt 
database created. Output 1 will improve access to information and knowledge sharing through 
an MSME portal through which MSMEs will be able to get information on any aspect of the project 
and lodge grievances on any problems faced. Judgment debts against MSMEs, awarded by the 
courts, need to be centrally captured to give a financial picture of the MSMEs to the banks. 
Currently, the judgment debt records are kept manually and no central database exists. Creation 
of the judgment debt database will provide a central repository of all judgment debts.

21.  Output 2: Citizen service centers established. One option for making BDSCs financially 
sustainable is to expand the current BDSCs to serve as CSCs. It will provide an opportunity for 
the BDSCs to conduct training programs for MSMEs, and also be critical for ensuring sustainable 
revenue generation after project implementation. Under the project, it is proposed to set in place a 
suitable risk-sharing mechanism between public and private sectors to establish the CSCs on a 
PPP format.19 Furthermore, solar power technology will be considered in establishing the CSCs.20

E.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
24.  Implementation  arrangements  will  follow  those  proven  effective  under  the  PSDP,  as 
summarized  in  Table  3  and  described  in  detail  in  the  project  administration  manual.23 The 
government, ADB, and IDB will review implementation based on quarterly reports from the PMUs 
and on consultant reports.24 The accounting, auditing, and reporting will be maintained under the 
project loan implementation. The procurement of consulting services will be in accordance with 
ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time), with final 
clearance of the selected consultants by ADB. Similarly, IDB’s financing will be in accordance with 
its financing agreement and procurement guidelines. ADB will not be administering the IDB-
financed LCF of $7 million or CSF of $2 million.

25 The PMUs will be responsible for the overall coordination of the project implementation. A certified, reputed local

8     
III.  DUE DILIGENCE 
 
A.  Technical  
 
25.  As noted in the Maldives country partnership strategy (footnote 8), capacity constraints 
severely affect the optimal use of externally assisted projects. Due to lack of experience by project 
implementation units, some projects are completed with delays of 3–4 years, undermining their 
development effectiveness. Against this background, three PMUs were established under the 
PSDP. Their performance was satisfactory and they played an integral part toward the successful 
implementation of government projects. Accordingly, PMUs will be set up at MED, MMA, and 
BML, and their project directors will be assisted by consultants. 
 
B.  Economic and Financial 
 
26.  Based  on  the  economic  analysis,  the  project  is  expected  to  have  several  economic 
benefits: (i) $5 million increment in the gross domestic product (GDP) by 2016 as local sourcing of 
economic activity gains from broader access to credit, (ii) a more positive balance of payments 
through an assumed 10% increase in exports and 20% reduction in imports, (iii) tax revenues of 
approximately $2.4 million, (iv) minimum $12 million of add-back to GDP through a reduction in 
nonperforming  assets,  and  (v)  $15  million  incremental  turnover  in  the  MSME  sector.  Other 
economic  benefits  include  lower  government  payroll  expenditure  as  MSMEs  generate  jobs, 
increased lending appetite of banks and additional funds available for credit, and a robust finance 
sector with better credit judgment resulting from access to information through the CIB  and 
establishment of the STR.  
 
27.  A financial analysis was carried out in accordance with ADB guidelines. All financial costs 
and benefits have been expressed in nominal terms. Cost streams used todetermine the financial 
 
internal rate of return (i.e., capital investment, and operation and maintenance) reflects the cost of 
delivering the estimated benefits.26 Besides the returns expected from the CIB as a result of 
expanded  membership  and  increased  sale  of  reports,  interest  income  owing  to  fewer 
nonperforming assets and interest savings owing to less foreign debt have been included in the 
revenue stream. The financial internal rate of return of nearly 12% compares favorably with the 
standard cost of capital of slightly above 4%, indicating substantive financial viability for the 
project. Nonquantifiable financial benefits, increased capacity of MSMEs, better access to credit 
information, and other related benefits are not included.  
 
C.  Governance 
 
28.  Financial management and procurement capacity assessment, undertaken during the fact-
finding mission in October 2011, indicates that MOFT and the three implementing agencies can 
manage loan proceeds during project implementation. The PMUs at the implementing agencies 
have experience in financial management and procurement in accordance with ADB requirements, 
 
 
                                                
26 With operation and maintenance cost taken as 10% of the infrastructure cost, the total operation and maintenance 
expenditure beyond the project period is estimated at $0.39 million. The depreciation rate is assumed at 15%. The 
incremental turnover of the MSME sector as a result of the project is estimated at $15 million on account of a new 
loan injection. Given the tax–GDP ratio of 15.7% (2009 World Bank data), the tax revenue by the end of the project 
period is estimated at $2.4 million, with 50% to be accrued by the third year and 100% by the fourth year, beyond 
which it is assumed to stay static.

9  
and a satisfactory track record from the PSDP.27 Planned mitigating measures include adopting a 
sequential  approach  in  line  with  lessons  from  the  PSDP,  strengthening  the  PMUs  through 
monitoring consultants’ performance, and capacity building interventions. During the fact-finding 
mission, ADB also conducted an evaluation of BML and found that it is eligible to operate as a 
financial  intermediary.  The  manuals  and  processes  that  are  in  place  under  the  PSDP  for 
administration of the various interventions would also significantly contribute to risk mitigation. 
ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed with the 
government. The specific policy requirements and supplementary measures are described in the 
project administration manual.  
 
D.  Poverty and Social 
 
29.  The  project  will  target  population  groups  across  the  country  and  will  lead  to  the 
development of new and existing MSMEs, thereby generating jobs, particularly among women 
and the youth. The services provided by the BDSCs are aimed at increasing the competitiveness 
of MSMEs and supporting export promotion.  
 
30.  To ensure gender mainstreaming, the project will support interventions designed to boost 
entrepreneurship and build marketable skills for women and the youth. Interventions will include 
public awareness, capacity building and training, research and studies for gender issues, and 
priority in accessing business development services. A gender action plan will be implemented to 
ensure inclusiveness in the project and to meet the unique needs of women and vulnerable 
groups, the views of which will be solicited with respect to any proposed legislation or legal 
amendments. The use of temporary special measures to increase women’s participation in MSME 
development will be encouraged. By supporting less-developed areas of the country, the project 
will help minimize geographical inequality and contribute to balanced regional development, and 
ultimately contribute to improving the Gini coefficient.  
 
E.  Safeguards 
 
31.  The project is categorized as ―FI treated as C‖ for environment, involuntary resettlement, 
and  indigenous  peoples. The  project  is  unlikely  to  have  any  adverse  environmental  impact. 
Rather,  it  will  explore  nonconventional  energy  sources  for  MSMEs  to  reduce  their  carbon 
footprints. MSME action under the additional LCF will only be for subprojects or activities that (i) 
are not included in the list of prohibited investment activities set out in Appendix 5 of ADB’s 
Safeguard Policy Statement (2009); and (ii) have minimal or no adverse environmental impacts in 
accordance with the Safeguard Policy Statement, and in compliance with Maldivian laws and 
regulations.28 The  project  is  required  to  comply  with  applicable  government  environmental 
regulations and standards. No involuntary resettlement and impacts on indigenous peoples are 
anticipated.    
 
F.  Risks and Mitigating Measures 
 
32.  Major risks and mitigating measures pertain to (i) political transition and changes in the 
                                                
27 Since the project is an extension of the PSDP and the tasks envisaged under both are similar in nature, similar 
governance and corruption risks are expected for both projects. The key governance risk pertains to interference in 
project management. All risks arise from the possibilities of influencing the objective sanction of credit through the 
LCF, misuse of the LCF, lack of engagement of participants, deficiencies in the operation of and resultant gaps in 
information generated by the CIB and the proposed STR, and inability of beneficiaries to meet expectations. 
28
 The LCF guidelines will include a set of subloan eligibility criteria as set out in the PAM and financing agreement. The 
screening checklist will be developed by the project management consultants at MED, and training for relevant 
safeguard capacity development will be provided to staff at MED and bankers at BML.

10     
composition of the senior counterparts,29 (ii) lack of internal capacity for project implementation 
and management, (iii) capacity issues in the judiciary to enforce legal reforms coupled with 
absence of political will to implement the required legal reforms, and (iv) interference in the 
selection  of  beneficiaries  under  the  project.  Adequate  risk  mitigation  measures  have  been 
envisaged through a significant grant input, which will support capacity development and set up 
the PMUs as a separate output. The risk of interference has been mitigated through detailed 
documentation of procedures for the granting of benefits. As the risks can be mitigated to a 
manageable level, the intended benefits and impacts are expected to outweigh the costs.30  
 
IV.   ASSURANCES 
 
33.  The government has assured ADB that implementation of the project shall conform to all 
applicable ADB policies, including those concerning anticorruption measures, safeguards, gender, 
procurement,  consulting  services,  and  disbursement  as  described  in  detail  in  project 
administration manual and loan documents. The government has agreed with ADB on certain 
covenants for the project, which are set forth in the loan agreement. 
 
34.  Conditions  for  Disbursement.  Notwithstanding  any  other  provision  of  the  financing 
agreement, no withdrawals will be made from the loan account (i) for LCF activities until the BML 
subsidiary loan agreement and at least two of the onlending agreements will have been executed 
by the beneficiary and BML, and BML and a qualified enterprise respectively all in form and 
substance satisfactory to ADB; and (ii) for CIB and STR activities under Outputs 2 and 3 of 
Component 2 (Access to Finance) until the MMA subsidiary financing agreement, in form and 
substance satisfactory to ADB, will have been executed by the government and MMA.  
  
V.  RECOMMENDATION 
 
35.  I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board approve  
(i)  the loan in various currencies equivalent to SDR3,622,000 to the Republic of the 
Maldives  for  the  Inclusive  Micro,  Small,  and  Medium-Sized  Enterprise 
Development Project from ADB’s Special Funds resources with an interest charge 
at the rate of 1.0% per annum during the grace period and 1.5% per annum 
thereafter; for a term of 32 years, including a grace period of 8 years; and such 
other terms and conditions as are substantially in accordance with those set forth 
in the draft financing and project agreements presented to the Board; and 
(ii)  the grant not exceeding $4,450,000 to the Republic of the Maldives from ADB’s 
Special  Funds  resources  for  the  Inclusive  Micro,  Small,  and  Medium-Sized 
Enterprise Development Project, on terms and conditions that are substantially in 
accordance with those set forth in the draft financing and project agreements 
presented to the Board. 
 
 
Haruhiko Kuroda 
President 
27 April 2012

instability are likely to be minimal, irrespective of changes in the political leadership. Based on historical experience, it 
is expected that the agenda for reforms and the political will to continue with it would not suffer any setback because 
of economic compulsions.
